The adverbs probably and definitely usually come after will but before won't:
strawberry
Can you read the [k]recipe[/k] to me? My hands are messy.
potato
[k]Maybe they'll[/k] like this restaurant.
tomato

We could make tomato sauce for the pasta.

Definitely has the strongest meaning and shows that we are sure about what we're saying.
definitely might not
They'll maybe
probably
[k]He[/k] [k]may[/k] [k]be able to[/k] [k]help you[/k] [k]with the project.[/k]
The adverb maybe usually comes at the beginning of a clause:
onion
[k]They[/k] [k]might[/k] [k]want[/k] [k]to meet you[/k] [k]first.[/k]
James
Bake the bread.
My favourite fruit is strawberries, but I also like bananas and pineapples. My least favourite fruit is oranges.

It probably won't rain tomorrow.
to cut
banana
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Probably shows that we think something is likely, but is less sure than 'definitely'
We might be better to take the bus.
We use the verbs may and might to say that there is a possibility that something will happen. They are less sure than using 'will' and 'won't'
Sure, no problem. Where are you up to? Have you [k]added[/k] the onions yet?
will
Stir for 15 minutes.
Maybe is used to say that we are less sure about something.
to boil

We will probably visit them this year.
She'll definitely leave soon.
They probably won't arrive on time.
We definitely won't go there again.
We don't usually use the adverbs 'probably', 'definitely' and 'maybe' with the verbs may and might:
[k]We[/k] [k]definitely[/k] [k]won't[/k] [k]be coming here[/k] [k]again.[/k]
Which kinds of fruit do you like most?
True or false?
Claire
to fry
The food delivery [k]will probably[/k] arrive before 7 o'clock.
will might
With will and won't we can show that things are more or less probable by using adverbials like definitely, probably and maybe.
Here you go. Thanks a lot for your help. Bye.
Greengrocer
